math_problem.A1677: Find all functions $f$ such that $f(x^{3}+y^{3}+x y)=x^{2} f(x)+y^{2} f(y)+f(x y)$ for all real numbers $x$ and $y$.

math_problem.A1693: Find a sequence of maximal length consisting of non-zero integers in which the sum of any seven consecutive terms is positive and that of any eleven consecutive terms is negative.

{
  "reasoning": "Problem 1: From the given functional equation, substituting special values (including y = -x and y = 0) shows first that f is odd and that f(0) = 0. One derives the key identity f(x^3) = x^2 f(x) for all real x. Using this and further substitutions, one obtains a linearity-type relation that forces f(x+2) to differ from f(x) by a fixed constant multiple of 2, and comparing with the already-derived cubic relation shows that f must be linear through the origin. Checking f(x) = c x in the original functional equation confirms that all such functions work, and no other functions do. So the full set of solutions is f(x) = c x for arbitrary real c. \n\nProblem 2: Let s_k be the partial sums of the sequence (with s_0 = 0). The condition that every sum of 7 consecutive terms is positive translates to s_k > s_{k-7} for all k >= 7, and the condition that every sum of 11 consecutive terms is negative translates to s_k < s_{k-11} for all k >= 11. Considering only indices that are multiples of 7 gives a strictly increasing chain s_0 < s_7 < s_14 < ...; considering multiples of 11 gives a strictly decreasing chain s_0 > s_11 > s_22 > .... Because 7 and 11 are coprime, their least common multiple is 77. If a sequence had length at least 77, then index 77 would be both a multiple of 7 and 11, forcing s_77 > s_0 and s_77 < s_0 simultaneously, which is impossible. Hence the length n satisfies n <= 76. One can construct (by solving the corresponding system of strict inequalities for partial sums and then taking integer differences) a concrete sequence of 76 nonzero integers satisfying the required window-sum sign conditions, so 76 is attainable and therefore is the maximal possible length.",
  "answer_1": "f(x)=cx for all real x, where c is any real constant",
  "answer_2": "76"
}
